marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, and then all the party
were placed along the course, here and there here was no "One, two,
three and away!" but they began running when they liked and left off
when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over.
However after running for a half  hour or so and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out,
"The race is over" and they all crowded around it  panting and asking "who  has won" This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought.
At last it said, "_Everybody_ has won, and _all_ must have prizes." "But who is to give the prizes?" quite a chorus of voices asked. "Why, _she_, of course," said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one
finger; and the whole party at once crowded 'round her, calling out, in
a confused way, "Prizes! Prizes!" Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand into her
pocket and pulled out a box of comfits (luckily the salt-water had not
got into it) and handed them 'round as prizes. There was exactly one
a-piece, all 'round. Lewis Carroll " Alice in Wonderland"

It seems like everyone is now saying that there will be a deal with the EU by Friday or nothing. (Note that in my last prediction I thought the negotiations could and probably would move into March. That appears unlikely now.) Current polls point to a potential narrow victory for staying in the EU right now, though a lot of big voices on the conservative side seem to be lining up against it. The consensus also seems to be that a later vote would have a better chance of shifting towards Brexit (which makes me wonder about June, since that's really not that close.) So here's what I think: 1. If Cameron gets a deal on Friday, i say there's a 90% chance that he calls a June vote. He's fought too hard to get the deal; delaying a vote on it would be interpreted as him being unsatisfied with it, and then he's screwed. The 10% represents the possibility that he gets a deal that is so bad that it's widely scorned, and the polls swing immediately towards Brexit. In that case he might find some kind of way to weasel out of a June vote.  2. Conversely, if Cameron doesn't get a deal, the vote probably gets delayed. There will be enough conservative chest-thumping to shift the polls, and Cameron will be seen as weak. It will be pretty much back to the drawing board for the pro-EU side, and they'll need a delay. The fall-back position for Cameron and the EU is to say they'll try to work it out in March, but at this point I think even that much delay would push the vote back far enough for a no on this question. If there is no deal, I predict a 90% chance that the vote will be delayed long enough that it's not set by May 1. 3. So what are the odds of Cameron getting a deal? I'm a pessimist on that, mostly because it requires unanimity from the EU and they still have some issues of genuine and important disagreement (France doesn't want London financial institutions to be less regulated, and the eastern European countries don't want German to have the emergency brake.) My finger-in-the-air number is 40%.  So: P = 40%*90% + 60%*10% = 42% I expect this to change (possibly dramatically) in the next few days.

Let's start with the outside view. The first fact to note is that PM David Cameron has promised to hold a referendum on the UK's membership in the EU (a.k.a. Brexit[1]) before the end of 2017. (Both the Economist[2] and the BBC[3] have impeccable overviews.) How likely is it that Cameron will follow through on his promise? Pretty likely, I think. I'd be willing to make about a 100-to-1 bet in favor but not much lower, so let's say there's a 99% chance that there referendum will be held by the end of 2017. For the moment, I'm going to ignore this possibility, but I'll factor it back into the mix later. And I think it's safe to assume that the date for the vote would have to be announced no later than the end of September 2017. It's now (roughly) half of the way through February, so in order for Britain to set a date for the Brexit vote before the end of 2017, it has to do so in the remaining 19.5 months. Assuming that the date on which the Brexit vote is set is randomly determined, the probability of that Britain will set a date prior to May 1, 2016 is 1.0-(17/19.5) = 0.128. Why? Per the above, I'm assuming that our probability space is made up of the following discrete outcomes: Britain announces the vote in February 2016 = Pr(0.5/19.5)
Britain announces the vote in March 2016 = Pr(1.0/19.5)
Britain announces the vote in April 2016 = Pr(1.0/19.5)
Britain announces the vote in May 2016 = Pr(1.0/19.5)
Etc...
Britain announces the vote in September 2017 = Pr(1.0/19.5) So 1 (i.e., the entire probability space) = (0.5/19.5)+(1.0/19.5)+...(1.0/19.5) (i.e., the probability that the announcement will be made in any given month). Another way to put the matter (which will be useful below) is in the following way: Britain announces the vote in 2016 = Pr(10.5/19.5)
Britain announces the vote in 2017 = Pr(9.0/19.5)
From here, it's just a matter of separating the probability that the announcement will be made in (the remainder of February), March, or April of 2016 (=2.5/19.5 = 12.8%).  But let's complicate matters a bit. Cameron has said a number of things that suggest he strongly favors having the vote in 2016. For example, he recently said, "I believe that 2016 will be the year we achieve something really vital, fundamentally changing the UK's relationship with the EU and finally addressing the concerns of the British people about our membership."[4] Some other political leaders in Britain have also expressed a preference for having (or at least a willingness to have) the vote in 2016[5]. That suggests that strongly weighting the probability that the date will be set in 2016. I'll incorporate this fact in my model (rather crudely) as a 3-to-1 bet that the vote will be announced in 2016 as follows: Britain announces the vote in 2016 = Pr(15.5/19.5)
Britain announces the vote in 2017 = Pr(4.0/19.5) Hence, the probability of that the Brexit vote will be announced in a randomly determined month in 2016 = (15.5/19.5)/12 = 7.0%. The exceptions are January (probability = 0 since all of that month is in the past) and February (probability = 3.5% since half of that month is in the past). On these assumptions, it follows that the probability that the vote will be announced before May 1, 2016 is 7% + 7% + 3.5% = 17.5%. This number should decrease by 17.5/75 (= about .233) every day as we approach May 1, so that it will be (17.5 - (3.26))% on March 1, and so on. Finally, let's return to the the very small possibility that Cameron will back out on his promise to hold the Brexit vote. I rated that as about a 100-to-1 shot. So today the outside view should be that there will be a 17.325% (17.5 x 0.99) chance that the Brexit vote will be announced before May 1. And it means that on March 1, there will be a 14.098% ((17.5 - (3.26)) x 0.99) chance that the Brexit vote will be announced before May 1. So much for the outside view, but what about the inside view? Cameron has signaled that he'd like the referendum to be held on June 23[6]. However, ongoing negotiations with Brussel looks to make it impossible for him to announce this date until after the European Council summit on 18/19 February, or perhaps as late as 22/23 February. Moreover, some think that Cameron has good reason to want the Brexit vote sooner rather than later. "Mr Cameron’s chances of victory improve the sooner he holds it. He does not want another terror attack or more refugee chaos to turn the referendum into a vote on immigration."[7]
Others mutter that British public opinion has already turned against EU membership[8 and 9 and 10] and that Cameron's best hope for keeping the UK in the the EU is to stall[11]. And there's a lot of uncertainty in the currency market about how a Bexit vote would go down[12]. (Ideal speculation: It seems to me - I lived in the UK for 4 years during the 2000s but am no expert about its politics - that nativism among Tory voters has gotten out of the control of conservative leadership in the UK in much the same way that nativism among Republican voters has gotten out of the control of conservative leadership in the U.S.A. Brexit in the U.K., and Trumpism is the U.S.A. But, to repeat, this is just ideal speculation.) At any rate, the inside view is harder to estimate because of the qualitative (rather than quantitative) nature of the data. But I think about an 88% probability of announcing the Brexit vote before May 1 is right. Where are we then? Outside View: 17.325%
Inside View: 88.0% So do we go with the outside view or the inside view? The obvious response is the we don't have to chose between the two; we can synthesize the view points. Yet that's damn hard, given the lack of isomorphism between the kinds of data I've got in front of me (and the squirrely way I came up with the inside estimate. A unweighted average of the two numbers is 52.66%. But at the moment, I have a lot more confidence in the inside view, that confidence might change a lot after Cameron's negotiations with the EU conclude, so I'll need to keep an eye on that. But until then I favor a weighted average of the inside and outside views, placing 3 times as much weight on the inside view. That means I'm forecasting 70.33% (rounding up to 71%) probability that Britain will set a date for a referendum on EU membership before May 1. However, I'll need to rethink this as soon as the EU negotiations are concluded. https://pythagorassite.wordpress.com/2016/02/14/before-1-may-2016-will-britain-set-a-date-for-a-referendum-on-eu-membership/ -- [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum [2] http://www.economist.com/news/britain/21690053-renegotiation-britains-eu-membership-mainly-theatre-it-may-be-enough-david [3] http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32810887 [4] http://www.euractiv.com/sections/uk-europe/cameron-drops-big-2016-hint-brexit-referendum-date-320599 [5] http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/26/british-eu-referendum-when-what-who-answers-to-key-questions-brexit [6] http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/640853/When-is-the-EU-referendum-June-23-Brexit-David-Cameron [7] http://www.economist.com/news/britain/21690053-renegotiation-britains-eu-membership-mainly-theatre-it-may-be-enough-david [8] http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3440970/EU-President-Donald-Tusk-says-talks-David-Cameron-s-EU-deal-fragile.html#ixzz3znHsHXqN [9] http://www.theweek.co.uk/eu-referendum/65461/eu-referendum-poll-support-for-brexit-highest-in-two-years [10] http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eu-referendum-cabinet-minister-set-to-push-for-brexit-within-minutes-of-cameron-europe-deal-a6871406.html [11] http://www.ft.com/fastft/2016/02/03/cameron-pressured-to-hold-brexit-vote-later-than-june/ [12] http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-15/u-k-markets-pounded-and-brexit-vote-doesn-t-even-have-a-date

It might happen in March, but the sides seem pretty far apart.  Also, it seems that the financial Masters of the Universe have started to put some shots across Cameron's bow (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-02-10/hsbc-board-said-to-meet-sunday-to-mull-headquarters-decision), lest anyone forget that there's a $hitload of money at stake. Cameron has pledged a vote by the end of 2017. That's a long way off, and he probably has the room to push that somewhat. I think the only way he sets a date for a vote is if there is (1) a deal in place to vote on that he EU has agreed to, or (2) a complete breakdown of EU negotiations.  I don't see #2 as likely, since this is the EU and they can negotiate on anything even remotely technical until the end of time. (See my predictions on the TTIP: in a word, nope). I say 5%. As far as a getting a deal goes, I think there may be eventually be one, but this is really going to rub a lot of EU members the wrong way, particularly in light of how many of them have been taking in large numbers of refugees lately. To be blunt, the only reason that the UK can even plausibly argue for such stringent anti-immigration provisions is because they're an island nation. I don't think that will sit well with the average German who just watched Merkel pledge to take in 1 million refugees. Any deal that is stringent enough to to satisfy UK conservatives is likely to require a lot of political feather smoothing in the other EU countries. That takes time, so I'm betting that the chance of a deal being agreed to in time to allow for a date to be set by May 1 is about 25%.

This has some interesting info on the timespan of the various stages between announcing a referendum and it being held
http://capx.co/parliamentary-rules-make-june-referendum-ambitious/ Key points: there is a 10-week campaign period before the day of the vote. Before that the electoral commission have to appoint the lead campaign groups pro- and con-  - at present the pro-Brexit side, in particular, is divided, and riven with tensions (see http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/12126762/Tory-MP-Bernard-Jenkin-fails-in-bid-to-oust-Dominic-Cummings-and-Matthew-Elliott-from-Vote-Leave.html ) , so selecting the lead parties may not be straightforward or prompt. The Electoral Commission have stated this process could take six weeks. And before that there is the matter of obtaining parliamentary approval, in both the Commons and Lords, for two statutory instruments.   Key point here (bearing in mind the narrow Tory majority in the Commons:  "Usually, Parliamentary business managers allow six weeks for such instruments. But there will be only a four week gap after the February European Council and the date on which a shortened designation process must begin in time for a June 23rd poll. Yet the Scottish Nationalists, and the Democratic Unionists have said they will vote against a June date on the not unreasonable grounds it will overshadow their elections."  None the less, that article assesses that 23rd June is still the most likely date for a referendum (and PM Cameron, who is pro-EU may be considered to favour the poll being held sooner rather than later, as numerous issues that show the EU in a poor light - perhaps above all the migration crisis - might well tip the balance of opinion in the direction of Brexit). But, still, that means time is short, and something that Cameron is prepared to present to his public needs to be agreed by February - not any later. Does the will exist in Brussels to present Cameron with something that goes someway towards assuaging concerns in his party and the British populace more generally about EU centralisation? It is as yet uncertain. As is how hard Cameron is prepared to argue for a case to which  he may or may not be wholeheartedly committed.

Base rate: needs to be set realistically before Autumn 2016 (let's say Oct 1st) for execution before end of 2017. Later than this, and politically Cameron would be seen as dragging feet. Therefore, number of months before (3) over number of total months (8): BASE = 38%. The main thing likely to make it happen sooner is good progress on UK renegotiations. These second round ones last weekend seem to have gone well: Cameron (BI.com), Jan 21st: "People said we wouldn't keep our promise but we've kept our promise and we are giving a referendum. The people will see that we have a proper negotiation going and already we've made very good progress. As my children would say in the car, 'are we there yet?' — no we're not. There is a possibility for these issues to be sorted and there has been real movement in the negotiations. I think it is achievable and doable but we're not there yet. I am satisfied the European partners will get this done. If there is a good deal, I will take it." The next critical point will happen over March 17-18 (the third EU summit at which Cameron would have debated UK renegotiations). This seems to me to be the most likely tipping point for setting the date for the REF itself (unlikely to be in Jun/Jul, but possible; more likely to be in autumn, and less likely to shift to 2017). I would add 20pp to my base rate on reports over progress, and timeline of key events (above) before 1 May. This results in 58%. If no solid reported progress is made over Mar 17-18, I will probably reconsider my forecast to a revised base rate.

COMMENT:  There does seem to be significant optimism that by mid-February the EU will have given Cameron assurances of  reforms that he can take to the voters in the UK.  The amount of debate over whether the vote will be called for late June, July, or at some later date suggests to me that people are pretty sure a vote will be this year, and sooner rather than later.

Support to leave the EU is slowly growing in the UK, but it is already slightly over 50%. So sooner is better to stem the growing support, but he will not be willing to set a date until he is confident that the decision will be to stay in the EU, which means he cannot set the date until he moves support for leaving to below 50%. If an agreement with the EU is reached by March, and it is favorable enough to the UK to move the level of support to leave the EU back to the minority, Cameron will want to set a date as soon as he can to lock in the support to stay.  I've assigned a probably of .85 to a deal with the EU being reached, because the consensus seems to be that a deal is wanted to both sides. If a deal is reached, I expect that there is a .9 probability that it will be favorable enough to move the support to leave the EU to safely below 50%, since there is little point in a deal for Cameron if it can't move the needle in the right direction for him.

"But he downplayed the prospect of treaty change, and indicated Cameron might get nothing more than a declaration of EU leaders at February's summit committing to future treaty change.  That would be a similar model to that used by the governments of Ireland and Denmark when they changed their terms of membership. "The form is important because Mr Cameron has repeatedly stressed the importance of the deal being “irreversible” and legally watertight. Ministers fear it could be unpicked by European judges, or reneged on by other states, if it is not “properly nailed down”, and Brexit campaigners will seize any opportunity to describe it as flimsy. "Mr Faull said there are a “range of possibilities” including “simple declaratory statements by the European Council”.  Other options include European legislation or treaty change, but “some think it is preferable to resolve these issues within the current treaties if at all possible.”  The Irish and Danish models – a political agreement to change the treaties at a later date – is “obviously a technique which has been used and is available to us”, he said. “A decision of the heads of state or government of the European Council can constitute an agreement between them in international law, and can quite legitimately be described as legally binding therefore."

I have done more research on secondary legislation mainly to satisfy my curiosity.  Unlike the US, the UK does not have a strict separation of powers doctrine and their executive and legislative branches are intertwined.  The delegation of authority from Parliament almost always goes to someone who answers to Parliament.  Although I have not found anything that says royal assent is not needed for SI’s, it makes sense based on how their system is set up.  The UK’s efforts in the last ten years to better separate the judiciary from the other branches is very interesting.

#1 FORECAST    13JAN16 Pathways to take the decision to set a date: 
A) treaty change
B) protocol
C) intergovernmental agreement 1.  First, the negotiation with the EU (and Member States) after which one of the above pathways 'kick-in':  
 > this is scheduled to reach 'mutually satisfactory solutions' in the European Council on 18-19 February [2]. The next European Council meeting is 17-18 March and then 23-24 June [4]
DURATION: 1 to 5 months, based on assumtion the negotiation has to finish before summer 2016, so June Council meeting, to meet the referendum deadline before 2017. PLAN A: TREATY CHANGE
3.  Signing a 'legally-binding and permenant' deal [3,5]:  
> there are two ways to change the treaties: (1) 'ordinary revision procedure' this means that the European Council may decide by a simple majority, after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament [6] after which the amendments enter into force after being ratified by all the Member States. And (2) the 'simplified revision procedure' which requires a unanimous decision by the European Council and again ratification by Member States or in a second option of the simplified revision 'that no objection is made within 6 months'. In both cases a consultation rounds lengthening the proces. To me it is unclear which route will be followed, please Reply if someone knows. DURATION:
OUTSIDE-IN: there have been 4 Treaty chances involving the above procedures of which only 2 where ratified: establishing the European Stabilisation Mechanism and increasing the members of the European Parliament. The first took 4 months, the second 14 months: averaging 9 months. INSIDE-OUT: a crucial and slightly overlooked item is that the European Parliament has to consulted and give consent AND that national governments have to agree/ratify. The key point is that the national governments of Hungary, Slovakia and especcialy Poland have aired to require substansive quid-pro-quo if Britain wants to restrict migrant benefits (mainly afecting Poles and Hungarians) -for example a stronger NATO presence. This last item could only be agreed on 8-9 July during next NATO meeting. My next update I'll look into the Parliament stance. 
- the official June 2016 date was mentioned in summer 2015, but this was before the missed deadline to finish negotiations in December. TREATY CHANGE DURATION: 5 months minimum to 20 months maximum, taking the mean as 9 months. PLAN B: PROTOCOL  [7]
- There is a likelihood that Britain will settle for a protocol or some other binding declaration that will be formally ratified only if and when a future treaty is in the works which could be resemble concessions offered to Denmark and Ireland in the past and ratified only later. If this protocol would be reliable enough, the referendum could still be held.  PROTOCOL DURATION: 
- OUTSIDE IN: 12 months for the Irish Lisbon treaty opt-outs and 11 for the Danish decision. Average: 7 months when substracting 3 months to hold the Irish and Danish referenda. 
- observation: the 4 months was only achieved in the teeth at the height of the financial crises.
- this will require Cameron breaking the pledge to obtain the legally-binding and permenent agreement. PLAN C: INTERGOVERNMENTAL TREATY
- this involves all Member States to sign a treaty which was used 4 times, one in 2005 and the other three more recent being the 'Fiscal Compact', 'Stability Mechanism', and 'Single Resolution Fund Agreement'. The first two took 4 months, the last 9 months  [8]. Average: 5,5 months.
-Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany’s finance minister. He suggested a so-called “intergovernmental treaty,” 4.  Finally, announcing the referendum
DURATION: 1 to 4 weeks, some preparations and scheduling has to be done (assuming most preparation have allready been made). TOTAL DURATION:
- averaging TREATY CHANGE, PROTOCOL and INTERGOVERNMENTAL TREATY gives 7,2 months (standard deviation 2 months). Time to 1th of May is 3,75 months. 
- Chance given by probability calculation (baysian): 4%. FORECAST: 7%    (slight upward adjustment taking the current 42% Good Judgement consensus into account)

Cameron has promised  a referendum. The public and political classes expect it. He can't hold it in 2017 due to elections in France and Germany. He can't hold it in July due to Scottish school holidays. He can't hold it before March, because negotiations with EU will not get anywhere before then, and because the secondary legislation that is required to set the rules will be introduced too late. The date has to be in September, specifically 15 September. The date must be announced 16 weeks ahead of the referendum. That is by 26 May 2016. So the question is whether Cameron will announce before 1 May or sometime between 1 May and 26 May. The European Council meeting is 17-18 March. There are 44 days between 18 March and 1 May 2016. There are 26 days between 1 May and 26 May 2016. Seventy days in all when Cameron could conceivably announce a date for the referendum. 63% of them are before 1 May. Should I forecast 63%? Probably. But right now I don't see what purpose Cameron would have in postponing the inevitable until May. So I'm going with 75% for the time being.

COMMENT:  From all I've read, Cameron wants the UK to stay in the EU, IF . . . Thus, he is trying to get the changes to the EU that he thinks will make membership more appealing to Brits, since it appears likely that a British referendum on EU membership will fail if there aren't reforms/changes in the relationship between the EU and Britain where some powers are returned to Britain.  Cameron is going to press for these reforms/changes at the next EU meeting Feb 18/19 and, if necessary, at the leaders' summit in mid-March.   A key demand Cameron is proposing is to restrict non-British EU citizens from accessing certain benefits during their first four years in the country; this proposal has not been well-received by some EU members.       An European Council declaration or Protocol, legally binding on all Member States (and inserted into the Treaty in due course), is likely to be the best that Cameron will be able to achieve in February or March.  If he gets it, I think he'll announce a referendum date shortly thereafter, otherwise, he'll delay setting a date.   Until the referendum is held, financial markets (which hate uncertainty) will be in turmoil; this is bringing pressure on Cameron to set a date and "get it over with."

Thanks to Isgold7 and alistaircookie for comments on potential motivations from various sides. I would just like to add comments on logistics:
a.  3 possible dates suggested were 2016 Apr, 2016 Jun and 2016 Sep.  (source: http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2015/09/when-will-the-eu-referendum-be-held-here-are-three-possible-dates/)
b.  PM needs to give 16 weeks notice prior to referendum (source: http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-33141819)
c.  Given where we are now and negotiation with EU still outstanding, 2016 Apr is out.
d.  For referendum in 2016 Jun, latest notice date is 2016 Mar 4th.
e.  Next EU summit is 2016 Feb 18/19th (http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/).
f.  Budget to be delivered on 2016 Mar 16th.  There might be implications that could pop up here (Source: http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eu-referendum-ten-things-you-need-to-know-about-david-cameron-s-negotiations-in-europe-a6780156.html)
g.   If referendum notice given prior to budget, Chancellor and PM could be expected to field related questions even if issues not addressed in budget.  Not fielding these appropriately would lose votes.  Fielding these properly would require PM and team to take into EU inputs (2016 Feb 18/19th) and work out consensus amongst different parties, and addressed in budget, prior to latest date of notice (2016 Mar 4th) - 12 days in all, weekends included.  Not impossible, but still challenging.
h.  If referendum notice given post budget, well past last notice date for 2016 Jun referendum.  No point rushing - makes more sense to incorporate further inputs and get better prepared.
i.   There's also a risk PM may decide to hold referendum in holiday months of 2016 Jul and Aug, in which case notice prior to 2016 May 1st couldn't be ruled out.  But this will invite skepticism: what's he running away from?  Not a risk to take on a matter of such importance.

The European Council meets in February, March, June, October, and December of 2016. http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/european-council/ First, Cameron has left open the possibility that the referendum could be in 2017 if negotiations sour. Since negotiations must be completed at least 10 weeks prior to the referendum, that means there would have to be an agreement by June to hold the referendum in 2016. However, based on the public comments from EU and UK leaders following the December meeting, it seems that a deal is in the works. Also, EU supporters have an incentive to wrap up negotiations as quickly as possible as the consensus seems to be that an earlier referendum is better for Brexit opponents. This suggests a willingness to reach a deal to allow for an early vote on the question.

Enough time has to be left for necessary legislation associated with the referendum (five weeks, say), and then enough time after that for the referendum campaign to take place (at least six week, probably eight), and the government will not want the referendum campaign to interfere with the General Election campaign, which has to occur in 2017.

If a referendum was held in June 2016 (the earliest feasible date) then it would have to be announced in Feb 2016. But this looks unlikely, as it would require the EU renegotiation talks to be completed at the EU summit in Feb 2016 *and* the referendum timeline to be set a couple of weeks later. That seems like a very tight timeframe. So a later referendum looks most likely (e.g. Autumn 2016 or Spring 2017) which allows the date to be announced after 1st May. It is possible that a date will be announced more than 16 weeks before the referendum takes place (this is what makes up most of my probability above) but there doesn't seem to be much advantage to the government to do this.

While I suspect the actual referendum will not be held until late 2016 or early 2017, I think the probability is relatively high that the current government will set the date of the referendum prior to 1 May.  While little apparent progress has been made on the negotiations for EU-UK treaty revisions and opt-outs, the upcoming election cycle in the UK (5 May 2016) and national elections in France and Germany in early-mid 2017 mean that the most probable window for a referendum would be mid- to late-2016, and an announcement prior to the UK local elections would likely benefit the current government (Conservative).  If no substantive progress is reported towards additional UK opt-outs or exemptions from EU treaties, or if conditions in the EU change dramatically (economically or otherwise), I could see the government making a case to postpone the referendum until late 2017 or even 2018, though that could lead to losses at the local election level for several years.

General EU and negotiation information Rights of EU citizens: Citizens of EU member countries are also citizens of the EU. As such, they are guaranteed certain rights. The EU prohibits any discrimination based on nationality. Citizens also have freedom of movement and residence within member states. Any EU citizen who resides in a member state can vote and run for local office just like a national of that country. See http://europa.eu/pol/pdf/consolidated-treaties_en.pdf#page=57 European Union, Consolidated Treaties, Part Two, Non-Discrimination and Membership of the Union. Britain’s exemptions from current EU policies:     Opt-out for the euro (Economic and Monetary Union)
    Opt-out for Schengen Agreement (abolished border controls)
    Opt-out for Justice and Home Affairs legislation (http://europa.eu/pol/justice/index_en.htm and http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-14-2266_en.htm )
    Opt-out for the Fundamental Charter on Human Rights http://www.europarl.europa.eu/charter/pdf/text_en.pdf See also “Europe ‘à la carte’: The whats and whys behind UK opt-outs” for more information about the opt-in and outs. http://www.euractiv.com/sections/uk-europe/europe-la-carte-whats-and-whys-behind-uk-opt-outs-314379#group_extlinks Britain’s demands from EU negotiations: Letter from David Cameron to Donald Tusk dated November 10, 2015 detailing areas for negotiation: https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/475679/Donald_Tusk_letter.pdf The four categories are: Economic Governance, Competitiveness, Sovereignty, Immigration (most controversial). The letter gives more specifics about each.

December 17, 2015 --Referendum Act passed; Referendum must be held no later than December 31, 2017. For text of Act:  http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/36/pdfs/ukpga_20150036_en.pdf Relevant time frames in Act: At least ten weeks prior to the referendum date, the government must publish a statement regarding negotiations with the EU,  rights and obligations of EU membership, and examples of countries with alternate arrangements with the EU At least four months prior to the referendum date, any changes to regulations governing certain communication and publication rules must be made. My first estimate:
Didn't really dig deep into this question, but as a starting point I am carefully optimistic.
The Tory government promised a referendum on EU membership by the end of 2017.
Votes and elections seems have been often held in March or September, so assuming this to be true the latest possible date within that time frame would be September 2017.
As a reference, the Scotland independence referendum took place on September 18th 2014, while the date was announced on March 21st 2013, so 18 monhts ahead.
With these very rough assumptions, I would see the date to be announced in March 2016.
In addition, there seems to be strong pressure from other EU countries to do the referendum rather earlier than later, and even Cameron's government seems to prefer an earlier date for the moment (there's even talks of "early 2016"). The government is arguing for a Yes, so will time the referendum in the best possible way to get that outcome. Hence in the coming months the things to look at are important events connected to the main concerns of British voters when it comes to the EU: refugees/immigration, economic development eurozone vs. britain, payments to vs. benefits from the EU.

In order for a referendum to go ahead at all, Parliament will need to approve an EU Referendum Bill. This is generally expected to happen by January 2016. An added complexity is a proposal by the House of Lords to lower the voting age for the referendum from 18 to 16 years. The Electoral Commission expects that once the EU Referendum Bill is in place, six months of preparations will be needed and on top of that another six months to register 16 and 17 years olds. (Source: http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-34708742 ). All this taken together will push the referendum well into 2017. I'm reasonably certain that Mr. Cameron would prefer to see most of the loose ends tied up before he sets a date for the referendum and announces that. This is a question which needs to be followed closely, as events unroll in the coming winter and spring. That said, I'm starting out with a forecast on the cautious side: 10%.

I take "setting the date" to refer to royal assent being granted to legislation calling a referendum having been approved by both houses of parliament. I am inclined to suspect the date will be set after the local elections to be held in many parts of England and Wales slightly later in May (and which , amongst other things, will serve as a test of the new Labour leadership, and evidence of public response to a UKIP whose public profile is rather lower than it has been for some time, and to a Conservative Party with around a year in majority government). Cameron does appear keen to call the referendum ASAP. The Government have earlier announced the intention to hold the referendum before the end of 2017 (but subsequently have appeared to give favour to a 2016 date) In terms of precedents, referendums in the UK are relatively rare, and a recent innovation. The most recent (and the only recent one to be held UK-wide), held on 5 May 2011 (on electoral reform), only had its date set by parliamentary vote three months earlier than that - obtaining royal assent on 16 February. The referendums on devolution to Scotland and Wales in 1997 again were held relatively shortly after they had been firmly approved. I don't have details to hand, but the referendums were held in September, and the Government that introduced them had only come to power in May. So, on these bases, were the date of a referendum to be agreed before 1 May 2016, the referendum could be expected to be held in the summer or early autumn of 2016. This is certainly not out of the question, but as yet nothing firm indicates this is the case. Another difficulty at present concerns the make up of the (now mostly appointed) House of Lords, in which the ruling Conservatives do not hold a majority, and have recently suffered some important defeats. The convention that manifesto promises are not opposed by the Lords *should* still hold, but many of the old rules or constitutional understandings that have historically guided Westminster politics are evolving rapidly at the moment.
